Why would options be bad in that case?

Because if the exit is an IPO and the price stays the same or goes below IPO price before lockup, options are worthless.  Options have a strike price which is typically set at the fair market value at the time of the grant.  So for example, you get 100 options at a strike price of $10 and the company IPOs at some point during the year and at the end of the year you can exercise 25 options.  If the current stock price is $10 or less you would be paying the same or more per share than the open market.  If it's greater than $10 you get (Current Price - Strike Price) * #shares = gross profit.  So if the stock was at $15 you would get (15 - 10) * 25 = $125 gross profit
